mainPage.title: History of Religion
mainPage.content:
Understanding Humanity's Search for Meaning

Religion has been central to human civilization from prehistory to the present day. This wiki provides an educational overview of major world religions and their historical development.

Why Study Religious History?

  • Cultural Understanding: Religion shapes art, law, ethics, and social structures
  • Historical Context: Many historical events are driven by religious factors
  • Contemporary Relevance: Religious dynamics influence modern geopolitics
  • Philosophical Inquiry: Religious traditions address fundamental questions about existence

Scope

This wiki covers major world religions in historical context, examining their origins, key beliefs, and impact on civilization. It aims to be educational and respectful of all traditions.

subpages.title: Ancient and Indigenous Religions
subpages.content:
Prehistoric Religion

Archaeological evidence suggests religious practice dates back at least 100,000 years. Early religions likely involved:

  • Animism (belief that natural objects have spirits)
  • Ancestor worship
  • Shamanism and spirit mediums
  • Burial rituals suggesting belief in afterlife

Ancient Mesopotamia and Egypt

Polytheistic religions with elaborate pantheons:

  • Mesopotamia: Anu (sky god), Enlil (wind god), Ishtar (love and war)
  • Egypt: Ra (sun god), Osiris (afterlife), Isis (magic and wisdom)

Greek and Roman Religion

The Olympian gods (Zeus, Athena, Apollo, etc.) influenced Western culture profoundly. Rome adapted Greek gods and eventually adopted Christianity as state religion (380 CE).

Indigenous Traditions

Indigenous religions worldwide share common elements: connection to land, oral tradition, ritual practice, and community-centered spirituality. Many continue today.

subpages.title: Abrahamic Religions
subpages.content:
Judaism

The oldest monotheistic religion still practiced, originating with Abraham (~2000 BCE). Key developments:

  • The Exodus and Mosaic Law (Torah)
  • First Temple (Solomon) and Second Temple periods
  • Rabbinic Judaism after Temple destruction (70 CE)
  • Medieval developments: Kabbalah, Sephardic and Ashkenazi traditions

Christianity

Founded on the teachings of Jesus of Nazareth (1st century CE):

  • Spread through Roman Empire; became state religion (380 CE)
  • Great Schism (1054): Catholic West and Orthodox East
  • Protestant Reformation (1517): Luther's challenge to Catholic authority
  • Today: ~2.4 billion adherents worldwide

Islam

Founded by Prophet Muhammad in Arabia (7th century CE):

  • Five Pillars: Shahada, Prayer, Zakat, Fasting, Hajj
  • Rapid expansion across Middle East, North Africa, and beyond
  • Golden Age of Islamic civilization (8th-14th centuries)
  • Sunni-Shia split over succession to Muhammad

subpages.title: Eastern Religions
subpages.content:
Hinduism

One of the oldest religions, developing in the Indian subcontinent over millennia:

  • Vedic period and the Upanishads (philosophical texts)
  • Key concepts: Brahman (ultimate reality), Atman (soul), Karma, Dharma, Moksha
  • Major deities: Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva, and many others
  • Diverse practices from temple worship to yoga and meditation

Buddhism

Founded by Siddhartha Gautama (Buddha) in India (~5th century BCE):

  • Four Noble Truths: suffering, its cause, its end, the path
  • Eightfold Path to enlightenment
  • Major branches: Theravada, Mahayana, Vajrayana
  • Spread to East and Southeast Asia

Other Eastern Traditions

  • Confucianism: Social ethics and proper relationships (China)
  • Taoism: Harmony with the Tao (Way), Wu Wei (non-action)
  • Shinto: Japanese indigenous religion, kami (spirits) in nature
  • Sikhism: Founded by Guru Nanak (15th century), monotheism and equality

subpages.title: Religion in the Modern World
subpages.content:
Secularization Thesis

19th-20th century thinkers (Weber, Durkheim) predicted religion would decline with modernization. This proved partly true in Western Europe but not globally.

Religious Revival

The late 20th century saw religious resurgence:

  • Rise of evangelical Christianity in Americas and Africa
  • Islamic revival movements
  • Hindu nationalism in India
  • New religious movements worldwide

Religion and Conflict

Religious identity intersects with ethnic, national, and political conflicts. Understanding religious dimensions is crucial for peace-building.

Interfaith Dialogue

Growing movements toward religious understanding and cooperation. Organizations like the Parliament of World's Religions (since 1893) promote dialogue.

Contemporary Trends

  • 'Spiritual but not religious' growing in Western societies
  • Religion and science debates continue
  • Digital religion and online communities
  • Religious responses to climate change and social justice
